questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening knee pain over the past 6 years. She reports stiffness in the morning that lasts for less than 30 minutes and worsens after prolonged activity. On physical examination, there is tenderness, and swelling in both knees, with reduced range of movements and crepitus. An X-ray of the left knee is shown below. Despite conservative treatment, her pain persists. She is counseled on intra-articular injections. Which of the following is not an option for intra-articular treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs)

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations and X-ray showing joint space narrowing, irregular joint surface, subchondral sclerosis, and osteophyte formation are consistent with a diagnosis of Osteoarthritis.
  • DMARDs target immune and inflammatory pathways to slow disease progression in conditions like Rheumatoid arthritis and are not used in osteoarthritis.

 

X-ray features seen in Osteoarthritis:

Radiological features

Pathology

Joint space narrowing

Focal areas of loss of articular cartilage

Osteophytes

Bone growth at the joint margins

Sclerosis of subchondral bone

Sclerosis of underlying bone

Bone cysts

Cyst formation in underlying bone

Bone attrition

Loss of bone

Apparent effusions

Varying degrees of synovial inflammation

Not visible on radiographs

Fibrosis and thickening of the joint capsule

 

Note: In severe cases, loose bodies are seen.

 

Treatment:

Supportive therapy:

  • Weight reduction
  • Stress management
  • Local heat provides relief of pain and stiffness
  • Quadriceps strengthening exercises - improve stability of the knee joint
  • No unnecessary knee movements.

Medical treatment:

  • Paracetamol
  • Topical NSAIDs
  • Intra-articular injections:
    • Local anesthetic (Option A ruled out)
    • Corticosteroid (Option B ruled out)
    • Hyaluronic acid (Option D ruled out)

Surgical treatment:

  • Osteotomy
  • Joint replacement (Partial or total) - in advanced disease stages
  • Arthroscopic procedures - minimally invasive procedures.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of diabetes presents with the changes as shown in the image below. Which of the following features is not consistent with the X-ray foot findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Decreased joint space

 

Explanation:

  • The given image is of Charcot’s foot
  • The 6 D's of hypertrophic Charcot joints include distention, density increase, debris production, dislocation, disorganization, and destruction.
  • Decreased joint space is not one of the 6 D's, as it typically refers to osteoarthritis or other degenerative joint diseases rather than hypertrophic Charcot arthropathy.

 

X-ray Features

 

Feature

Atrophic Charcot Joint

Hypertrophic Charcot Joint

Bone Resorption

Yes

No

Osteolysis

Yes

No

Common Location

Forefoot

Midfoot, rearfoot, ankle joint

Characteristics
  • Localized bone loss
  • Licked Candy stick appearance

6 D’s of Hypertrophy

  • Distended joints (Option A ruled out)
  • Density increases (Option B ruled out)
  • Debris production (loose body)
  • Dislocation
  • Disorganization (Option D ruled out)
  • Destruction

questions.text: Which of the following is a common joint pathology associated with the advanced stages of rheumatoid arthritis?

choices.text: Fibrous or bony ankylosis and joint subluxation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fibrous or bony ankylosis and joint subluxation

 

Explanation:

  • Chronic inflammation in rheumatoid arthritis leads to the destruction of cartilage and bone, which can cause the joint to become immobile i.e. ankylosis, either due to fibrous tissue or actual bony fusion.
  • Joint subluxation can also occur as a result of ligament and tendon damage, leading to misalignment of the joint.

 

Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a systemic disease.
  • It is the most common cause of chronic inflammatory joint disease.
  • Women >> Men.
  • Common age group: Fourth or fifth decades of life.

 

Etiology:

Genetic Predisposition:

  • Strong association with histocompatibility markers HLA-DR4/HLA-DR1.
  • HLA-DR4 is found in ~70% of people with RA.

Infectious Agents:

  • Possible involvement of mycoplasma, clostridium, and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) in genetically predisposed individuals.

 

Pathogenesis:

 

Immune Activation:

  • APC (Antigen-presenting cells)/T-cell interaction initiates immune response and release of cytokines.
  • Cell proliferation occurs in the synovium.

Cytokine Involvement:

  • Cytokines activate macrophages and B-cells.
  • B-cell activation leads to anti-IgG autoantibody production.

Chronic Inflammation:

  • Immune complexes deposit in synovial joints, enhancing inflammation.
  • Production of proteolytic enzymes, prostaglandins, TNF, and IL-1.
  • Cartilage matrix depletion and bone damage occur due to inflammatory factors.

Synovial Changes:

  • Synovium becomes edematous, infiltrated, and filled with fibrin exudates.
  • Hypertrophied synovium surrounds articular cartilage, forming a pannus.
  • Cartilage loses its smooth surface and becomes eroded; pannus extends into subchondral bone.

 

Joint Deformities:

  • Deformities due to muscle spasms, fibrosis, and soft tissue changes.
  • Advanced disease leads to fibrous/bony ankylosis and subluxation of joints.
  • Osteoporosis develops in adjacent bones, and peri-articular tissues become edematous.

 

Osteophyte formation (Option A): It refers to the development of bone spurs, commonly seen in osteoarthritis (OA) rather than rheumatoid arthritis (RA). 

 

Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes (Option C): These nodes are associated with osteoarthritis. Heberden's nodes occur at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, while Bouchard's nodes occur at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints.

 

Bone cyst formation (Option D): They can occur in osteoarthritis due to bone remodeling, but they are not a common feature of rheumatoid arthritis.

Correct Answer: A) Felty's syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The unknown joint and bone condition the patient is suffering from is most likely Rheumatoid arthritis based on the presence of characteristic hand deformities (swan neck and boutonniere deformities).
  • Felty's syndrome is a severe extra-articular manifestation of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis (RA), characterized by the triad of RA, splenomegaly, and neutropenia.
  • This syndrome predisposes patients to infections due to neutropenia.

 

Clinical features of Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Symmetrical polyarthritis, polysynovitis with soft-tissue swelling- Pain and morning stiffness in multiple joints usually lasting more than 30 minutes.
  • Generalized myopathy or neuropathy, tiredness, and loss of weight.
  • As the disease progresses, joint deformity, joint instability, and tendon rupture.

 

Joints affected

Common
  • MP joints of the hand
  • PIP joints of fingers
  • Wrists, knees, elbows, ankles

Less common
  • Hip joint
  • Temporo-mandibular joint
  • Spares sacroiliac joint and distal inter phalangeal joints.


 

Deformities in Rheumatoid arthritis

Hand
  • Ulnar deviation of the hand
  • Swan neck deformity
  • Boutonniere deformity

Elbow

  • Flexion deformity

 

Knee
  • Valgus deformity

Ankle

  • Equinus deformity

Foot
  • Hallux valgus

 
  • Hammer toe

 

Extra-articular manifestations of Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Vasculitis
  • Rheumatoid nodules- Subcutaneous, over bony prominences, in the synovium, on tendons, in the sclera, and the viscera. Size is increased by methotrexate.
  • Serositis
  • Felty's syndrome: Severe splenomegaly + neutropenia + RA. (Option A)


 

Psoriatic arthropathy (Option B):

  • It is a chronic inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis.
  • It can cause joint pain, swelling, and deformities, but it is typically associated with nail changes like pitting, and dactylitis causing sausage-shaped fingers. 

 

Kashin-Beck disease (Option C):

  • It is a rare polyarticular form of osteoarthritis commonly seen in regions of China.
  • It primarily affects growing children and causes joint deformities, leading to dwarfism.
  • It is not associated with neutropenia, splenomegaly, and typical hand deformities as seen in this patient. 

 

Pseudogout (Option D):

  • It is caused by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints, leading to sudden and painful joint inflammation.
  • It does not cause swan neck and boutonniere deformities, neutropenia, and splenomegaly.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, primarily affecting her hands and wrists. She reports that the stiffness is worse in the morning and lasts for over an hour. On examination, there is tenderness and swelling in multiple small joints, and her grip strength is reduced. An X-ray of the hands is shown below. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR, C-reactive protein (CRP), positive rheumatoid factor (RF), and normal liver function tests and complete blood count. After temporary symptom relief with NSAIDs which of the following is the first line of treatment in this patient?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Methotrexate

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations, X-ray findings (marginal bone erosion in the left 5th metacarpophalangeal joint and joint space narrowing with marginal bone erosion in the right 4th and 5th proximal interphalangeal joints) and blood investigations are consistent with a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for rheumatoid arthritis in patients with active disease for reducing disease activity and preventing further joint damage.

 

X-ray:

  • Early changes- soft-tissue swelling and periarticular osteoporosis.
  • In later stages- marginal bony erosions and narrowing of the articular space.

 

Numerous periarticular joint erosions (arrows) and joint space narrowing

 

X-ray AP of the hand: Periarticular osteopenia; reduced radiocarpal and intercarpal joint spaces; erosions (arrows), and subluxation of the metacarpophalangeal joints (white circles). Ankylosis of the intercarpal joints (asterisk).

USG and MRI: They are useful in detecting soft-tissue changes and early erosions.

Blood investigations:

  • Normocytic, hypochromic anemia.
  • RF (Rheumatoid factor) is present in 80-90% of patients with RA.
  • ACPA (Anti-citrullinated protein antibodies) is present in 70-80% of patients.
  • Antinuclear factors are present in 30%
  • In acute phase, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and levels of C-reactive protein (CRP) are raised.

 

Treatment:

Acute Stage:

  • Active disease
  • Corticosteroids are used temporarily.
  • Pain- Non-steroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs)

Medical treatment: (Options A & C ruled out)

  • DMARDs
    • HCQ (Hydroxycloroquine)
    • Sulfasalazine
    • Methotrexate (1st line of treatment) (Option D)
      • Avoided in patients with liver disease, and latent Tuberculosis.
    • Leflunomide (if mehtotrexate is not tolerated) (Option B ruled out)
  • Biologic DMARDs
    • TNF inhibitors:
      • Infliximab
      • Etanercept
      • Golimumab
      • Certolizumab
      • Adalimumab
    • Inhibitors of T-cell costimulation - Abatacept
    • IL-6 - Tocilizumab
    • B-cell depleting therapies - rituximab
  • Injection of corticosteroid
  • Physiotherapy and occupational therapy
  • The ACR (American College of Rheumatology) recommends that RA patients should receive vaccination for pneumococcus, hepatitis, influenza, human papillomavirus (HPV), herpes zoster virus (HZV), and COVID-19 before starting therapy.

Surgical management:

  • Synovectomy, tendon repair, replacement, joint stabilization, and osteotomy.
  • In late stages with severe joint destruction, fixed deformity, and loss of function: reconstructive surgery.

questions.text: In primary osteoarthritis, systemic and mechanical factors interact to trigger the early stages of cartilage degeneration. Which of the following is the earliest pathological change observed in osteoarthritis?

choices.text: Increased water content in the cartilage

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Increased water content in the cartilage

 

Explanation:

The first change observed in osteoarthritis is increased water content (microscopic change) and loss of proteoglycans from the cartilage matrix, weakening the cartilage structure.

 

Osteoarthritis (OA):

  • It is the most common form of arthritis in the world.
  • It mainly affects the hips, knees, spine, hands and feet.

 

Types:

  • Primary OA:
    • It occurs in a joint de novo without any underlying cause.
    • It occurs in old age, mainly in the weight-bearing joints (knee and hip).
  • Secondary OA:
    • An underlying primary disease of the joint leads to degeneration of the joint.
    • Commonly occurs at the hip.
    • Trauma or injury, congenital joint disorders, inflammatory arthritis, avascular necrosis, infectious arthritis, Paget disease, osteopetrosis, osteochondritis dissecans, metabolic disorders (hemochromatosis, Wilson’s disease), hemoglobinopathy, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, or Marfan syndrome.

 

Major risk factors for OA:

  • Systemic predisposition:
    • Genetics
    • Age
    • Gender- Women, especially post-menopausal
    • Diet and obesity
  • Local biomechanical factors:
    • Abnormal joint shape and size
    • Previous injury/trauma
    • Neuromuscular problems
    • Obesity
    • Loading/occupational factors

 

Pathogenesis:

  • Systemic and local mechanical factors interact to initiate the osteoarthritis process.
  • Primarily articular cartilage is affected.
  • The first change observed is increased water content (microscopic change) and loss of proteoglycans from the cartilage matrix, weakening the cartilage structure. (Option B)
  • Progressive softening and disintegration of articular cartilage occurs due to continued mechanical stress.
  • As the cartilage wears away, the underlying subchondral bone becomes exposed. (Option D ruled out)
  • Associated with new growth of cartilage and bone at joint margins forming osteophytes. (Option C ruled out)
  • Loose flakes of cartilage can incite synovial inflammation, leading to capsular thickening and joint deformity. (Option A ruled out)
  • Often, only one compartment of the joint is more affected.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening knee pain over the past 6 years. She reports stiffness in the morning that lasts for less than 30 minutes and worsens after prolonged activity. She denies any history of trauma or systemic inflammatory disease. On physical examination, there is tenderness, and swelling in both knees, with reduced range of movements and crepitus, tenderness over proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, along with squaring at the base of the thumb. X-rays of the knees show joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis. Which of the following findings in PIP joints is characteristic of her condition?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bouchard’s nodes

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestation and X-ray findings suggest that the patient is most likely suffering from osteoarthritis of both the knees and hands.
  • Bouchard’s nodes are bony swellings that occur at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and are characteristic of osteoarthritis.

Clinical manifestations

Symptoms:

  • Pain (Nature and severity are variable)
  • Joint stiffness (short-lasting stiffness after a period of inactivity)
  • Fatigue
  • Sleep disturbance
  • Reduced functional ability and activities

Signs:

  • Tenderness of the joint
  • Bony swelling
  • Reduced range of movement with pain at the end of the range
  • Crepitus on movement of the joint
  • Weakness and wasting of muscles around the joint
  • Signs of inflammation (mild)
  • In severe cases - deformity and instability
  • Varus deformity and fixed flexion deformity of the knee

Varus deformity

 

  • Commonly affected joints in the hand: Distal interphalangeal joints (DIPs) and the thumb base
  • Classical findings in hand:
    • Heberden’s nodes (posterolateral swellings of DIP joints) (Option C ruled out)

 

    • Bouchard’s nodes (posterolateral swellings of PIP joints) (Option A)
    • Squaring at the base of the thumb (first CMC joints)

Kashin Beck disease:

  • An extremely rare polyarticular form of OA.
  • Seen in the people of Northern China and Eastern Siberia.
  • Symptoms:
    • Joint pain
    • Polyarticular swelling
    • Deformity from childhood
    • Short stature
  • X-ray:
    • Distorted epiphyses and tubular long bones.

 

Boutonniere deformity (Option B):

  • This deformity is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and involves hyperflexion at the PIP joint and hyperextension at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint.

Rheumatoid nodules (Option D):

  • These are firm, non-tender lumps under the skin commonly seen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), typically in areas like the elbows.
  • They are not a feature of osteoarthritis and are not related to PIP joint involvement in osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with swelling and limited mobility in her right shoulder, having experienced a sudden onset three weeks ago. Upon inspection, the right shoulder is swollen, non-tender, and erythematous. She reports a history of unnoticed burns on her hands and neck from cooking and using a hairdryer. An MRI of the cervical spine is given below. An indium WBC scan was performed, and the result was negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Charcot arthropathy

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is a case of Charcot’s arthropathy of the shoulder joint due to syringomyelia because:
    • A history of unnoticed burns suggests a significant loss of sensory function, likely due to the syrinx in her cervical spine (as shown in the MRI).

    • Acute onset of non-tender swelling in the shoulder indicates acute arthropathy.
    • The negative indium WBC scan indicates the absence of acute infection, which would be expected in cases of osteomyelitis or septic arthritis.

Charcot Joints (Neuropathic joint): Progressive, degenerative & destructive joint disorder due to abnormal pain sensation & proprioception

 

Joints involved:

  • Foot and ankle
  • Shoulder
  • Elbow
  • Knee
  • Hand

 

Most Common Joint Involved: Foot

  • 60%: Tarsometatarsal joint
  • 30%: Metatarsophalangeal joint
  • 10%: Ankle joint


 

Etiology:

Cause

Mechanism

Common Joint Involved

Diabetes mellitus (Most common cause)

Peripheral neuropathy leads to altered pain sensation and proprioception

Foot

 

Syphilis (Tabes dorsalis)

Neurological deficits affecting joint function

Knee

Syringomyelia

Dilatation of the spinal cord; may lead to syringobulbia (if it extends to the Brainstem)

Shoulder

Leprosy

Neuropathy leading to loss of sensation

Hand and Foot

Meningomyelocele

Neurological deficits impacting joint function

Variable, but often lower limbs




 

Osteoarthritis (Option A): typically presents as a chronic condition and does not explain the association with the syrinx on MRI.

 

Osteomyelitis (Option C): would likely show positive findings on an indium WBC scan and typically presents with systemic signs of infection, which are absent in this case.

 

DVT (Option D): could cause a tender swelling and would not explain the neurological symptoms associated with the syrinx.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female with a 15-year history of diabetes presents with a chronic charcot foot deformity in her right foot, accompanied by recurrent ulcerations. She has previously undergone treatment with total contact casting but continues to have instability and pain. What is the next best step for her?

choices.text: Management with offloading and regular follow-up
Schedule surgical arthrodesis with internal fixation
Refer for amputation of the affected foot

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Schedule surgical arthrodesis with internal fixation

 

Explanation:

  • Surgical arthrodesis with internal fixation is indicated for patients with chronic Charcot foot deformities who experience instability and recurrent ulcerations despite conservative treatment.
  • It will effectively stabilize the affected joints, alleviate pain, and reduce the risk of further ulceration, making it a definitive management strategy.
  • Restore a plantigrade foot, improving the patient's overall function and quality of life.

 

 

Treatment

Details

General Treatment
  • Vascular Management:
    • Vasodilators improve blood flow
    • Pentoxifylline enhances RBC flexibility, promotes wound healing, and maintains vascularity.
 
  • Infection Control: Antibiotics are essential for managing and preventing infection.

Acute Arthropathy
  • Immobilization: Minimizes movement to protect the affected area
  • Total Contact Casting (TCC) :
    • Provides pressure relief while allowing mobility
    • Encase foot and lower leg, redistributing weight with regular checks for fit(weekly) & replace them every 2 weeks.
    • The aim of TCC is to keep the patient mobile

Chronic arthropathy
  • Rest: Essential for recovery and reducing stress on the affected area
  • Braces: Patellar Tendon Bearing (PTB) Brace supports mobility and redistributes pressure

  • Orthotics: Charcot Restraint Orthotic Walker prevents further damage to Charcot’s joint.

  • Surgical Treatment

 

  • Includes Open Reduction Internal Fixation (ORIF) for complex fractures
  • Excision of bony prominences
  • Reconstruction to restore structure
  • Arthrodesis to fuse joints
  • Amputation in severe cases.

 

Management with offloading and regular follow-up (Option A): While offloading is important, this patient has already failed conservative treatment and requires a more definitive solution.

 

Initiate pharmacologic therapy with bisphosphonates (Option B): Pharmacologic therapy may help reduce bone resorption but does not address the underlying deformity or instability.

 

Refer for amputation of the affected foot (Option D): This should only be considered if all other options have failed or if the patient's condition is unsuitable for further surgery. In this case, surgical intervention is warranted.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with a history of severe hemophilia A presents with recurrent episodes of knee swelling and pain. On examination, his knee shows significant effusion and tenderness, and the physician suspects pathologic changes in the joint. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of the joint changes observed in this condition?

choices.text: Increased osteoclast activity leading to bone resorption
Hyperplastic vascularity and inflammation in the synovial membrane
Accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joint space
Immune-mediated damage to the cartilage due to systemic inflammation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hyperplastic vascularity and inflammation in the synovial membrane

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is a case of hemophilic arthropathy.
  • Hyperplastic vascularity and inflammation in the synovial membrane is characteristic of haemophilic arthropathy, resulting from recurrent bleeds leading to chronic joint changes.

 

Etiopathogenesis:

 

Coagulation Pathway

Altered intrinsic pathway leading to bleeding tendency

Types of Hemophilia
  • Type A (Absence of factor VIII, 85%)
  • Type B (Absence of factor IX, 15%)

Primary Cause

Chronic and recurrent exposure of articular cartilage and synovium to metabolized blood products

Consequences of Blood in Joint
  • Hypervascular synovial hypertrophy
  • Chronic synovitis
  • Articular cartilage damage
  • Bony hypertrophy
  • Subchondral cysts
  • Joint surface loses its luster and becomes eroded in” Rivet-like tracts”
  • In end-stage disease, the densely pigment-stained hyperplastic membrane undergoes metaplasia to fibrous tissue, and contractures develop, eventually leading to fibrous ankylosis

 

Increased osteoclast activity leading to bone resorption (Option A): is more relevant in conditions like osteoporosis

 

Accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joint space (Option C): are associated with gout

 

Immune-mediated damage to the cartilage due to systemic inflammation (Option D): occurs in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis where the immune system attacks joint tissues, leading to inflammation and cartilage destruction.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy with hemophilia B presents for a follow-up appointment. He has a history of recurrent hemarthroses in his left knee, which has progressively become painful and swollen. The physician orders an X-ray to assess the current state of the joint. Which of the following stages is most consistent with the given X-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stage 3

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is a case of Hemophilic arthritis
  • Given image shows a widened intercondylar notch, which belongs to Stage 3 of Arnold & Hilgartner radiological classification of hemophilic arthritis

 

Radiological stages of Hemophilic arthritis

(Arnold & HilgartnerRadiological Classification)

 

Stage

Findings

I
  • No skeletal abnormalities
  • Soft tissue swelling

II
  • Osteoporosis
  • Overgrowth of epiphysis.

  • No erosions.
  • No narrowing of cartilage space

 

III
  • Early subchondral bone cysts
  • Squaring of the patella.

  • Intercondylar notch of distal femur and humerus widened.

  • Cartilage space remains preserved

IV
  • Findings of stage III more advanced.
  • Cartilage space narrowed significantly

V
  • End stage.
  • Fibrous joint contracture
  • Loss of joint cartilage space
  • Marked enlargement of the epiphyses
  • Substantial disorganization of the joints

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with severe hemophilia A presents to the emergency department with a swollen, painful right knee after falling while playing a few hours ago. His mother reports that he has had similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is the next best step?

choices.text: Administer oral NSAIDs and discharge home
Perform joint aspiration and factor replacement
Immobilize the knee in a flexed position

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Perform joint aspiration and factor replacement

 

Explanation:

  • This is a case of acute hemarthrosis as noted by the time of onset.
  • In acute hemarthrosis in hemophilia, the immediate focus should be on an aspiration to relieve pressure and pain, combined with factor replacement to correct the coagulation defect.



 

Management

 

Acute Hemarthrosis
  • Aspiration: Aggressive management with aspiration of the joint.
  • Factor Replacement: Regular replacement of clotting factors (e.g., Factor VIII/IX) to prevent further bleeding.
  • NSAIDs: Use of Cox-2 inhibitors or ibuprofen for pain relief.
  • Bupivacaine & Corticosteroids: Instillation during aspiration to reduce rebleeding risk.
  • Bed Rest & Immobilization: Strict bed rest and limb immobilization in extension.
  • Emergent Considerations: Special care for immature hip to prevent osteonecrosis.

Primary Prophylaxis

Initiated in infancy to prevent future hemarthroses and long-term disability.

Surgery (Elective)
  • Pre-Surgery Factor Replacement:
    • Infusion 2 hours before surgery to achieve 100% factor activity
    • continuous infusion to maintain >60% during and after surgery.
 
  • Post-Surgery Monitoring: Check factor levels immediately after and then every 1-2 days.

Chronic Arthritis
  • Synovectomy:
    • Open or arthroscopic synovectomy for recurrent hemarthrosis
    • recommended if bleeding occurs >3 times in 6 months.
 
  • Radiosynovectomy:
    • For patients with multiple joint involvement or inhibitors.
    • With Yttrium 90 silicate or Phosphorus 31 colloid
 
  • Surgical Principles: (Post & Telfer)
    • Tight wound closure
    • No electrocautery, wound suction
    • Avoid certain medications post-op.

Specific Surgical Interventions
  • Knee: TKA indicated in advanced cases; patellar resurfacing recommended.
  • Elbow: Radial head excision with synovectomy for recurrent hemarthrosis.
  • Hip: Total hip replacement for good outcomes.
  • Shoulder: Arthrodesis or prosthetic replacement options.
  • Ankle: Arthrodesis for chronic arthritis.

Flexion Contractures
  • Correction: Recommended correction of flexion contractures >30° before surgery.
  • Hamstring Release: For knee flexion contractures <45° not amenable to conservative treatment.
  • Osteotomy: Severe cases may require supracondylar osteotomy.

 

Complications:

 

Neurologic Complications:

  • Bleeding into the central nervous system (CNS).
  • Hemorrhage into major peripheral nerves.

Joint Complications:

  • Stiffness of affected joints.
  • Development of contractures.
  • Arthritis due to recurrent bleeding episodes.

Other Complications:

  • Compartment syndrome due to increased pressure from bleeding.
  • Blood-borne infections related to repeated procedures or factor replacement.

Administer oral NSAIDs and discharge home (Option B):

  • While NSAIDs can help with pain relief, they do not address the underlying issue of hemarthrosis.

 

Immobilize the knee in a flexed position (Option C):

  • Immobilization is important, but it should be done in extension to prevent further complications and allow for proper healing.
  • Flexing the knee could exacerbate swelling and pain.

 

Refer for immediate surgical synovectomy (Option D):

  • Surgical synovectomy is not indicated in the acute setting of hemarthrosis.
  • It is reserved for chronic cases where conservative measures have failed.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female with a history of psoriasis develops joint pain. Which of the following genetic markers is most commonly associated with psoriatic arthritis, but present in only 50- 60% of cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) HLA-B27

 

Explanation:

HLA-B27 is associated with psoriatic arthritis though it is present in only about 50-60% of cases.

 

Psoriatic arthritis

  • It is a chronic inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis.
  • The usual age at onset is 30–50 years.
  • It is usually seronegative (no rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies).
  • 20% of patients with Psoriasis develop arthritis.

 

Etiology:

  • Strong genetic component.
  • Associated with HLA B27 - only in 50-60%.

 

Pathology:

  • Chronic synovitis leads to cell infiltration and exudate, progressing to fibrosis.
  • Severe cartilage and bone destruction.
  • Sacroiliac and spine changes affect around 30% of patients.


 

HLA-DR4 (Option A): It is strongly associated with rheumatoid arthritis (70% of people with RA) but not commonly linked to psoriatic arthritis.

HLA-DQ2 (Option C): It is associated with celiac disease and not typically linked to psoriatic arthritis.

HLA-A30 (Option D): It is associated with type 1 diabetes, but it is not a common marker for psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the clinical manifestation of psoriatic arthritis?

choices.text: It can present with both distal interphalangeal joint arthritis and spondylitis.
Enthesitis, especially at the Achilles tendon insertion may be present.
Psoriatic arthritis typically presents with symmetrical arthritis in large joints.
Arthritis mutilans can lead to severe deformities in the fingers and toes.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Psoriatic arthritis typically presents with symmetrical arthritis in large joints.

 

Explanation:

This statement is false because psoriatic arthritis often presents with asymmetrical involvement, particularly affecting smaller joints like the distal interphalangeal joints, rather than exhibiting symmetrical involvement in large joints.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

Arthritis:

  • Asymmetrical oligoarthritis- common presentation
  • Symmetrical arthritis in some patients (Option C)
  • Distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) arthritis (Option A ruled out)

 

  • Arthritis mutilans - Fingers and toes are severely deformed due to erosion and instability of the interphalangeal joints. (Option D ruled out)

 

  • Interphalangeal arthritis and tenosynovitis
  • Sacroiliitis and spondylitis (Option A ruled out)
  • Heel pain (enthesitis) (Option B ruled out)

 

Ocular manifestation: Ocular inflammation- uveitis

Skin manifestations:

  • Sharply demarcated, erythematous plaque with silver scale.

  • Guttate lesions are small, erythematous papules generalized over the entire body surface area.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male with a 10-year history of psoriasis presents to the clinic with complaints of pain and swelling in his fingers and lower back stiffness for the past several months. On examination, there is swelling of the distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) of both hands, and tenderness in the sacroiliac region. His erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) are elevated, but rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are negative. Which of the following radiological findings is NOT commonly associated with his condition?

choices.text: Erosive changes and joint space narrowing
New bone formation and bony ankylosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Periarticular osteopenia with marginal erosions

 

Explanation:

  • The patient’s clinical manifestation with a background history of psoriasis is consistent with a diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis.
  • Periarticular osteopenia with marginal erosions is more commonly seen in rheumatoid arthritis rather than psoriatic arthritis.

 

Blood investigations in Psoriatic arthritis :

  • There are no laboratory tests specifically for psoriatic arthritis.
  • Raised erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP).
  • Negative Rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies.
  • HLA-B27 is present in 50–60%.

 

Radiological findings:

  • Erosive changes, gross joint destruction, joint space narrowing. (Option A ruled out)
  • Erosive changes, new bone formation, bony ankylosis, and joint osteolysis in hands and feet. (Option B ruled out)

Erosive osteoarthritis

 

  • Axial bones and joints - sacroiliitis and spondylitis; formation of syndesmophytes (ossification of the annulus fibrosis). (Option D ruled out)
  • USG and MRI are useful for detecting synovitis.

 

Treatment:

Medical:

  • NSAIDs
  • Immuno suppressive agents- methotrexate and TNF inhibitors
  • Local glucocorticoid injections
  • Physiotherapy

Surgery:

  • For unstable joints.
  • Arthrodesis procedure.
